titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Felix S. Cohen Papers Addition
titlestmt.author: by Jennifer Meehan

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Saturday February 9, 2019 at 04:07

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Felix S. Cohen Papers Addition documents aspects of Cohen's legal career as a civil servant, private attorney, and author, as well as his social, political, and professional activities. Included are files stemming from Cohen's work as a legislative draftsman and solicitor for the Department of the Interior, relating especially to Indian affairs and natural resources, and his work as a private attorney, relating to Indian affairs, immigration, and voting rights, including his manuscript notes for oral arguments in the cases of Trujillo vs. Garley and Harrison vs. Laveen; files relating to Cohen's various writing projects, comprising articles and reviews for law journals and published works, including Ethical Systems and Legal Ideals and The Legal Consicence ; and extensive files stemming from his activities with the Socialist Party and the National Lawyers Guild and, to a lesser extent, with various other social, political, and legal organizations, including the League for Industrial Democracy and the Institute for Living Law. Also found are some professional and personal papers.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Gene Cohen Tweraser and Karen Cohen Holmes, 2007.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Box 31 (sound recordings): Restricted fragile material. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Felix S. Cohen Papers Addition is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Felix S. Cohen Papers Addition. Yale Collection of Western Americana, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The addition was processed, arranged and described in 2007-2008. Arrangement was largely carried out in accordance with how the initial collection (Felix S. Cohen Papers, WA MSS S-1325) was arranged. Files arrived with no discernable order and extensive re-organization was required to arrange files into series and subseries. Descriptive information at the file level is based on a basic survey of the folder contents. Descriptive information about the collection as a whole was drawn in part from the finding aid for the Felix S. Cohen Papers, WA MSS S-1325.

relatedmaterial.head: Associated Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Associated material includes the Felix S. Cohen Papers, WA MSS S-1325.

bioghist.head: Felix S. Cohen (1907-1953)
bioghist.p: Felix Solomon Cohen was a lawyer with special interests in natural resources, in statehood and economic development for American territories, in Indian affairs, and in immigration and minority problems. He was a professor of jurisprudence, a civil servant, and an author of numerous articles on law, ethics, and philosophy, on Native Americans and minorities, and on human and natural resources. From 1933 through 1947 he served in the Solicitor's Office of the Department of Interior as an assistant solicitor, associate solicitor, and acting solicitor. He also served as chairman of the Office's Board of Appeals. Cohen drafted the Wheeler-Howard Act (later known as the Indian Reorganization Act) of 1934, and contributed to the department's handling of Indian and Eskimo aboriginal rights. In 1939 Cohen was named Chief of the Indian Law Survey, a joint project of the Lands Division of the Department of Justice and of the Department of Interior to compile all federal laws, treaties, etc., involving Native Americans. Cohen edited a summary of the 46-volume survey, which was published by the Interior Department as The Handbook of Federal Indian Law and remains a milestone in the evolution of Indian law. He received the Department's highest honor--the Distinguished Service Award--on retirement from government service in 1948.

Cohen re-entered private general law practice in January 1948, but continued to be interested in the legal affairs of Native Americans and immigrants, in human rights, and in natural resources. He eventually associated his Washington, D.C. office with the New York law firm of Riegelman, Strasser, Schwarz & Spiegelberg (which later became known in Washington as Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Kampelman). Cohen handled several important pro bono Indian cases, particularly two lawsuits, Trujillo vs. Garley and Harrison vs. Laveen, which established Native Americans' rights to vote in the last two states that had denied the franchise to them--New Mexico and Arizona, as well as cases securing their right to receive Social Security benefits.

In 1946, Cohen had begun teaching legislative drafting and legal philosophy at Yale University's Law School, and jurisprudence at The City College of New York's Department of Philosophy. Cohen had also taught at the New School for School Research and the University of Newark Law School (later Rutgers Law School). In 1951 he published Readings in Jurisprudence and Legal Philosophy , the syllabus which he developed with his father, Morris R. Cohen, for both their jurisprudence courses (Morris Cohen at St. John's Law School and Felix Cohen at Rutgers and the New School for Social Research).

Felix S. Cohen was born in Manhattan, but grew up in Yonkers, New York. He attended The City College of New York, received an M.A. in philosophy from Harvard in 1927 and a Ph.D. from Harvard in 1929. In 1928 Cohen entered Columbia Law School, graduating in 1931. He married Lucy M. Kramer that year; they had two daughters. He died at his home in Washington, D.C., in October 1953.
This biographical note is drawn from the finding aid for the Felix S. Cohen Papers, WA MSS S-1325.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Felix S. Cohen Papers Addition comprises the remainder of the collection that was donated in 1989 and 1991. The addition consists of material that was stored in the basement and other areas of the Cohen residence in Washington, D. C. and that came to light after the death of Lucy Kramer Cohen in 2007. The additional material spans the period from 1925 to 1960, with the bulk of the material dating from 1931 to 1953, and documents aspects of Cohen's legal career as a civil servant, private attorney, and author, as well as his social, political, and professional activities.

Included in the addition are files stemming from Cohen's work as a legislative draftsman and solicitor for the Department of the Interior, relating especially to Indian affairs and natural resources, and his work as a private attorney, relating to Indian affairs, immigration, and voting rights, including his manuscript notes for oral arguments in the cases of Trujillo vs. Garley and Harrison vs. Laveen; files relating to Cohen's various writing projects, comprising articles and reviews for law journals and published works, including Ethical Systems and Legal Ideals and The Legal Consicence ; and extensive files stemming from his activities with the Socialist Party and the National Lawyers Guild and, to a lesser extent, with various other social, political, and legal organizations, including the League for Industrial Democracy and the Institute for Living Law. Also found are some professional and personal papers.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is organized into five series: I. Legal Career, 1930-1955. II. Professional Papers, 1931-1960. III. Writing Projects, 1927-1960. IV. Organizational Affiliations, 1927-1954. V. Personal Papers, circa 1925-1960.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Legal Career series consists of files stemming from Cohen's work with the Solicitor's Office of the Department of Interior from 1933 to 1947 and with his private practice from 1948 to 1953.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This Legal Career series is arranged into four subseries: Indian Affairs, Indian Law Survey, Solicitor's Office Records, and Private Practice Office Records.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of Department of Interior files largely documenting the drafting and implementation of the Indian Reorganization Act of 1934 (IRA, known originally as the Wheeler-Howard Act) and routine legal work concerning the department's Indian policies. The files consist of internal memoranda, correspondence, drafts of reports and legal opinions, printed bills and drafts, and printed material by government agencies and private institutions.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Files are arranged in rough chronological order.

did.unittitle: Preliminary drafts of Indian Self-Government Bill
Wheeler-Howard Bill File, Drafts and correspondence
Wheeler-Howard Indian Bill, Correspondence, charter recommendations, atlas, publicity
General Notes on Proposed Legislation - Siegel, Shepard, Marshall
Department Report on Wheeler-Howard Indian Rights Bill
Hearings and testimony on Wheeler-Howard Act
Official Indian Vote on Wheeler-Howard Bill
Congressional Bills on Indian Self-Government, Drafts
Office of Indian Affairs, Radio Programs
Hearings, Reports and Speeches in Congress
Indian Claims Commission Act, Original Drafts
"Legislative Material on the Indian Claims Commission Act of 1946"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of files stemming from a joint project of the Department of Interior and Department of Justice, on which Cohen served as chief, to create a file of federal legislation and treaties concerning Native Americans. The project resulted in an internal publication entitled "Statutory Compilation of the Indian Law Survey: A Compendium of Federal Laws and Treaties Relating to Indians" and The Handbook of Federal Indian Law . The files consist primarily of memoranda, research material, and drafts.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Files are arranged in no particular order.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: More extensive documentation relating to the Indian Law Survey project can be found in the Felix S. Cohen Papers, WA MSS S-1325.

did.unittitle: Department of Justice Memoranda - Application Memos
"Chap. 3 Indian Treaties, Chap. 9 Individual Rights in Tribal Prop., Chap. 10 The Rights of the Indian in his Personality"
Lists of Court Cases Regarding Indian Affairs
Handbook of Federal Indian Law, Preliminary drafts, Chapters 1 and 3

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of files relating to Cohen's work with the Solicitor's Office on issues pertaining to natural resources, including government control of coal mines during the Second World War and the use of helium as an enery source. The files consist of memoranda, correspondence, drafts of reports and legal opinions, and printed material. Also found are various government publications.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Files within this subseries are arranged into three groupings: Coal Files, Helium Files, and Printed Material. Files within each grouping are arranged in rough chronological order.

did.unittitle: Regulations for the Operations of Coal Mines Under Government Control

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of files stemming from Cohen's private legal practice and relating to Indian affairs, immigration, and voting rights. Of particular note are Cohen's manuscript notes for his oral argument, of which no printed record exists, in the case of Trujillo vs. Garley, an Indian voting rights case in New Mexico.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Files are arranged in rough chronological order.

did.unittitle: Trujillo vs. Garley and Harrison vs. Laveen (New Mexico and Arizona voting rights) with notes
Trujillo vs. Garley, New Mexico's Voting Case - Manuscript Notes for Argument
"Summary Analysis of Proposed Omnibus Immigration Bill"
Briefs to Supreme Court of New York County
Joint Efforts General - Tabulations on Cases
Non-Joint Efforts - Office Memos, Briefs, etc.
Joint Efforts - Office Memos, Briefs, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of scattered papers and office files that relate broadly to Cohen's professional activities as a lawyer. Material found here overlaps with that found amongst the Legal Career files.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Material is arranged in rough chronological order. Miscellaneous and unsorted material are arranged at the end.

did.unittitle: French Report on U. S. Indians
Paper for 13th Conference on Science, Philosophy, and Religion
Papers from Conference on Moral Standards

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Writing Projects series consists of notes, background material, manuscripts and drafts, and correspondence relating to articles and book reviews by Cohen that appeared in various law journals and relating to his book, Ethical Systems and Legal Ideals , which was originally published in 1933; drafts for a work on Indian land values; notes and drafts for lectures on various topics; and correspondence and source material for the posthumous compilation of Cohen's writings entitled The Legal Conscience , edited by Lucy Kramer Cohen, which was published in 1960. Also found are scattered writings by others, and offprints and publications of writings by and about Cohen.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Writing Projects series is arranged into seven subseries: Articles and Reviews, Ethical Systems and Legal Ideals , Indian Land Values, Lectures, The Legal Conscience , Writings by Others, and Printed Material.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Files are largely arranged in rough chronological order. Miscellaneous and undated material are arranged at the end.

did.unittitle: Review of Boudin, "Government by Judiciary" - notes, manuscript
Review of Ehrlich, "Fundamental Principles of the Sociology of Law"
"The Relativity of Philosophical Systems and the Method of Systematic Relativism"
"What City College Will Contribute to the Development of Law"
Readings in Jurisprudence and Legal Philosophy
Encyclopedia articles on casuistry and Lorimer, James

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Files are arranged in no particular order.

did.unittitle: Labor, The Constitution and the Courts
Conference on Methods in Philosophy of the Sciences
"Ethics and Morals of Our Foreign Policy"
Source Material, I. Law and Ethics
Source Material, II. The Indian's Quest for Justice
Source Material, III. Studies in the Philosophy of American Democracy
"The Aesthetic and Metaphysical Bases of the Conflict of Laws"
"Felix S. Cohen: A Fighter for Justice"
A Jurisprudential Symposium in Memory of Felix S. Cohen, Rutgers Law Review

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Organization Affiliations series consists of material stemming from Cohen's participation and involvement with various social, political, and professional organizations. In particular, there are extensive files relating to Cohen's activities with the Socialist Party and the National Lawyer's Guild.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Organization Affiliations series is arranged into two subseries: Social and Political Organizations, and Legal Organizations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries largely consists of files relating to Cohen's involvement with the Socialist Party during the 1930s. Also found are files relating to his activities with the League for Industrial Democracy, the Alumni Committee on Academic Freedom at City College, the American Civil Liberties Union, and other social and political organizations. The files contain memoranda, correspondence, notes, report, minutes, publications, and other printed material.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Files are arranged by organization with printed material arranged at the end.

did.unittitle: Alumni Committee on Academic Freedom, City College
Continental Congress of Workers and Farmers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of files relating primarily to Cohen's activities with the National Lawyers Guild, where he served on the International Law Committee and National Executive Committee, as well as some files relating to his work the Intitute of Living Law. The files contain reports, memoranda, correspondence, background material, publications, and other printed material.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Files within the Legal Organizations subseries are arranged into two groupings: National Lawyers Guild and Institute of Living Law.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: More extensive documentation of Cohen's activities with the Institute of Living Law can found in the Felix S. Cohen Papers, WA MSS S-1325.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Files are arranged in no particular order.

did.unittitle: Correspondence regarding Spain and D. C.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Personal Papers series consists of Cohen's student papers, family scrapbooks, photographs, reel-to-reel tapes, other papers, and some papers of Lucy Kramer Cohen, documenting more personal aspects of Cohen's life.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Material is arranged largely by format.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: See also Family Scrapbook (from Series V)

did.unittitle: Clipping, Article on Felix S. Cohen in City College Campus Paper
Draft of Resignation Letter from Solicitor's Office and Clipping
Death certificate of Felix S. Cohen (copy)

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Reference copies are available and filed in the folders.

accessrestrict.p: Restricted fragile material. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.
